children.subject: Thanks! I didn't know there was a Piazza for that!
I'd recommend you also check out the Stat 001 Piazza for perspective on this

history.content:
<md>Stat 134 goes through most topics in CS 70 and more (negative binomial, beta distribution, poisson processes, R.V. transformations, correlated normal distributions). I personally found it to be very useful after CS 70 since it reinforced a lot of the probability topics that were covered relatively fast in 70. It is a pretty hefty time commitment though: you probably want to go through all the recommended practice problems as they are very useful and show up on the quizzes. Also Pitman's Probability (the standard textbook) is sometimes hard to follow, and leaves a lot of the intuition to the problems. The class is definitely a weeder (look at the distribution of grades on berkeleytime), so expect very difficult exams as well. However if you do put in the work and keep up with all the material, getting above a B+ should be reasonable. 

-------

I have Prof Lucas now for Stat 155 and he's pretty good.</md>

Stat 134 goes through most topics in CS 70 and more (negative binomial, beta distribution, poisson processes, R.V. transformations, correlated normal distributions). I personally found it to be very useful after CS 70 since it reinforced a lot of the probability topics that were covered relatively fast in 70. It is a pretty hefty time commitment though: you probably want to go through all the recommended practice problems as they are very useful and show up on the quizzes. Also Pitman's Probability (the standard textbook) is sometimes hard to follow, and leaves a lot of the intuition to the problems. The class is definitely a weeder (look at the distribution of grades on berkeleytime), so expect very difficult exams as well. However if you do put in the work and keep up with all the material, getting above a B+ should be reasonable.

children.subject: I would say less because it is not a proof-based class, and depends more on problem solving. However some parts of the course are quite conceptually challenging (the continuous probability section, specifically Chapters 4 and 6 of Pitman).
Compared to CS70's time commitment, would you say STAT 134 is more or less?
How's the workload of Prob 140 compared to CS 170?

Oh also I strongly plug Prob 140 if you've taken Data 8 or Data 100 (since prereqs are enforced). It's geared towards application of probability in data science as opposed to 134, which is more theory heavy. That being said, you can't go wrong with either

history.content:
Has anyone taken STAT 134 with Professor Adam R. Lucas? If so, how's the workload/time commitment? How hard is it to get a B+ or above? 

Also, if I'm taking CS70 right now, do you think it's a good idea for me to take in next semester?
history.subject: Has anyone taken STAT 134?
